values:
Well, if I spent November writing this crap for the mini_wrimo and then spent some more time making it marginally less crappy, why not post it? Not that this is any less crappy than the previous two or three Mini-Wrimo efforts...

Mine, about 4300 words, no warnings (unless some m/m cuddling deserves a warning). Some backstory can be found here

***** 
Visitor - by Quatorze

The door opened and closed with a click. He fumbled for the light switch, half embarrassed at his own excitement, and hesitated for a moment before turning it. It had been so long since he'd last brought someone to his home like this... damn, in fact this was the very first time since moving into this house. The first time he'd been out to a party this late, and most definitely the first time he didn't come home alone. Maybe that was why suddenly felt shy showing his place?
 
So silly, that. He switched on the lights, kicked off his shoes and glanced over his shoulder at the man behind him. "So, here we are."
 
"Yeah," his guest said, looking quite as shy and surprised as he was feeling. That was at least slightly encouraging, and they exchanged a little smile.
 
"Just make yourself at home," he said, "umm, would you like something to drink?" 
 
"Sounds good, actually."
 
"Okay. So, what'd you like, I know I have at least some beer in the house, maybe some red wine as well?"
 
"Beer sounds perfect, thanks." 
 
He knew his way around well enough so he didn't bother switching on the kitchen light, just strolled to the fridge and opened the door. Just as he was reaching for the bottles on the bottom shelf the guy behind him inhaled sharply.
 
"Holy shit!"
 
He wheeled around. "What is it?"
 
"What the fuck is that supposed to be?"
 
He blinked a few times at the gargoyle sitting on the kitchen top, wings neatly folded over its back, ears erect and that familiar sneer on its face. The pose was exactly right, the place not. When he'd left it had been right where it should: on the rocks of the little sedum garden. Most definitely not indoors. 
 
"That's, uhh, it's from the garden." He fumbled desperately for an explanation that wouldn't sound altogether too ludicrous. "Sorry, I'd totally forgotten that I brought it in for, umm, cleaning."
 
"Oh, okay." The guy chuckled a little, embarrassed at his own reaction. "Just startled me when the light from the fridge hit it. Looked so real there for a moment."
 
He managed a laugh that hopefully didn't sound too forced. "I know, I've sometimes mistaken it for a cat myself."
 
"Looks really alive, though," the guy repeated and stepped closer to inspect the gargoyle. "Wow, just look at all these colors! I've never seen anything like this before." 
 
"No?" he said as airily and conversationally as he could muster while picking out two bottles of beer. "Yeah, I think it's a rather special specimen."
 
"Amazing work, all these hues!" Of course the guy would be interested in something like that, what else could he expect? It was only natural, after all they had met at the art club, but given the situation it was also hugely inconvenient -- how was he going to distract his guest from the unexpected intruder? Jumping the guy and demanding sex that very moment did occur to him, but he quickly pushed the thought aside. That would be pushing himself too far.
 
And then he really had to catch himself because his guest bent even closer, fingertips ghosting over the gargoyle's back. "So exquisite... uhh, what?"
 
"What is it?" he asked, heart leaping into his throat. "Surely it's not broken or anything?"
 
"N-no," the guy said, hand hovering uncertainly just an inch or two above the thing. "It just feels so -- strange. Where did you get this?"
 
"Oh, I'm not sure." He could only hope that he didn't sound too flippant. "I think somebody from my earlier classes gave it to me, had bought it for his own garden but his wife didn't like it, or something. Maybe it was too big to her liking."
 
"Right." The guy took a step back and shook his head. "Such a funny texture, though, like it was covered with leather. And those colors, too! I wonder how they make something like that."
 
"Yeah, it really takes skill! Hey, do you want a glass?" He held the bottles in front of him in offering.
 
"No, I don't need one. Thanks." The guy took one of the opened bottles and took a swig from it, smacked his lips appreciatively and nodded. "Nice. Haven't tasted this brand before."
 
"My favorite," he said, "so I usually always have some at home. Come, let's sit down, the sofa is far more comfortable than the kitchen."
 
"Yeah, let's!" 
 
Just as he was about to follow the guy around the corner into the living room, he caught a minute movement in the corner of his eye and froze in his steps. 
 
"Hey, sit down and make yourself comfortable," he called, "I just realized that I'm not sure where I've put my phone, must find it because I think the battery was running low so I need to..." He made an audible show of fumbling for it and directed a stern glare at the gargoyle.
 
"If you dare move a single toe before tomorrow noon I promise I'll do something horrible to you," he hissed under his breath. "You hear me?"
 
The damn thing just grinned a little to him.
 
Heart beating faster, for more reasons than just expectation, he went into the living room with an apologetic little smile. "Sorry about that."
 
"No problem." The guy had settled in the middle of the sofa with the bottle in one hand. "Your place looks nice, by the way."
 
"Thanks." He hesitated for a while. What to do next? Would it be okay to sit on the sofa, too, or should he opt for an armchair instead? Fortunately his guest decided to take initiative.
 
"Hey, won't you sit down here?" The guy patted the sofa next to himself and smiled a little. "Or are you feeling shy all of a sudden?"
 
He went to the sofa and settled cautiously on it. "Maybe I am, but don't judge me too harshly, it's been a long time since I've last even been out, and let's not even talk about the last time when I was on a date."
 
The guy smiled. "You're forgiven. Just come over here, will you?"
 
He leaned closer and the guy kissed him. They had already kissed a couple of times at the bar but this kiss was far longer and more thorough. In fact it was long and thorough enough to make his confidence soar, so that when they after several minutes decided to take things to the bedroom it wasn't his guest who suggested it. 
 
They both slept like logs until light began to creep in through a narrow slit between the curtains. He blinked a few times, took a deep breath and smiled as he registered the warm body touching his under the covers. And then his pulse raced and eyes opened wide when the memory of the unwelcome sight in the kitchen suddenly surfaced.
 
For several moments he lay still, trying to calm his breath and figure out what to do, until he knew he wouldn't be able to stay in one place any more. He glanced at the guy sleeping next to him, hair tousled and a very slight stubble on his cheek, and began to wiggle away as quietly and gently as possible. He almost made it out of the bed, but just as he was easing his legs over the edge the guy stirred and opened his eyes.
 
"Uhh... what's it?"
 
"Nothing," he whispered, "I just need to take a leak. Will be right back."
 
"Oh." Apparently this explanation was satisfactory; the guy rolled over and settled back with a sleepy sigh. 
 
He sighed as well, out of relief, and tiptoed out of the bedroom and into the kitchen.
 
He had not realized how tense he had been before he stepped over the threshold and felt his shoulders sag at the sight of that familiar shape still huddled on the kitchen top, in exactly the same pose as on the night before.
 
The gargoyle did not move but he could see its eyes glint ominously. 
 
"Satisfied?" At least it had the decency to keep its voice down, so quiet that he had to strain his ears to hear it. 
 
"Yes," he replied under his breath. "How the fuck did you get in, and why? And don't give me any crap about the neighbour's unruly kids, or that it's cold outside. I know they haven't been on my yard and you don't care a rat's ass about how hot or cold it is."
 
"I was bored," it said, as if that would explain everything. "And I wanted more of that juicy stuff."
 
The cat food... What if they had come in only to find the gargoyle wrestling with a can of cat food on the kitchen table? The image made him want to giggle hysterically but he swallowed the urge and shook his head. "You'll have to wait until he leaves, I'm not giving you anything right now! And you still haven't explained how you got in. I know for a fact that I haven't left any doors or windows open!"
 
The tip of the gargoyle's tail twitched minutely. "Are you sure?"
 
"Yes!" he said firmly. "So either you know how to open doors, or else you've been lying to me and you can fly through walls or windows. Which is it?"
 
All he got by way of reply was a sharp-toothed grin.
 
"Don't give me that," he hissed. "Come on, tell me. How did you do it?"
 
"Cat food first," the gargoyle demanded. He shook his head.
 
"No," he said firmly. "Not before you tell me, and most definitely not until he has left. Now shut up and stay where you are."
 
"But don't you think it would be better if you told him that you have put me somewhere instead?" it bargained. He sighed.
 
"I think it would seem very odd if I had taken the trouble to move you somewhere, first thing in the morning. No, you stay right there and behave yourself. Shit, I should never have given you anything in the first place!"
 
And yet deep inside he couldn't help thinking that maybe he had no choice. If the thing could get into the house just like that... He shuddered at the thought and swore to himself that he'd squeeze the truth out of the damn creature no matter what it took. 
 
"Understood?" he demanded through clenched teeth. The gargoyle made a little snort.
 
"Of course, of course. Aren't we irritable now!"
 
It was his turn to snort. "You really have the nerve, calling me irritable! To think -"
 
His words were cut short when he heard the rustle of bedclothes from the other room, and in a flash he grabbed a glass from the table and ran some water into it. 
 
"Ewww, that was a used glass!" The tone was unmistakably mocking. He rolled his eyes.
 
"Yeah, so bite me."
 
The flash of teeth made his blood curdle just a little, and he put he glass hastily down. "Oh for fuck's sake, just shut up and remember what I told you!"
 
Heart pounding, he shuffled back to the bedroom, then remembered what he'd used as an excuse and stopped at the door. The guy reached a lazy arm towards him and wiggled his fingers. "Why don't you come back? I don't feel like getting up quite yet."
 
"Will be right there," he promised. "Just wanted a glass of water first."
 
A quick stop at the bathroom later, he crawled once again back to bed. The guy sighed and yawned, shifting to accommodate him.
 
"What time is it?"
 
"I dunno. Who cares, surely you don't need to be going anywhere today? It's Sunday, remember." 
 
"Hell, no. Wouldn't have gone out yesterday if I had work today."
 
One arm slid around his neck and the guy shuffled closer. "And you're off today, too, I remember you said so."
 
"Yeah." 
 
They kissed again and he did his best to relax, but it was proving damnably difficult because in the back of his head he knew that his ears were all the timed pricked to catch even the slightest sound from the kitchen. He groaned inwardly. Why today, of all days, right when he had company again after several dry years?
 
The guy was very persuasive, though, and it didn't really take all that long before he was getting into the mood again. Things were heating up nicely when -- 
 
CRASH!
 
They both sat up like they'd got an electric shock.
 
"Oh for fuck's sake," he growled.
 
"What was that?" The guy sounded genuinely frightened, and he quickly swallowed a yelled warning.
 
"I must've left the glass on the edge of the table," he improvised. "Here's to hoping it didn't shatter. I'll go check." 
 
He hurried to the kitchen, made a sudden stop at the doorstep, took a deep breath and switched on the light. The glass was indeed on the floor, fortunately still in one piece, and the gargoyle was where it should, although to be quite honest he hadn't quite expected to see it sitting so demurely on the kichen top. And yet something wasn't quite right with it.
 
"Tail," he growled under his breath, and just as he heard the steps behind him he saw the tip of the tail curl gracefully to exactly the same position it had been in the night. He glanced over his shoulder and grinned apologetically.
 
"Stupid me, I must've put it right on the edge. This has happened before when the table is just a little wet! Nothing broken, luckily."
 
He went to pick up the glass. The guy laughed a little.
 
"Seriously, doesn't that thing creep you out?" He pointed at the gargoyle.
 
"No," he lied so fluently that it surprised even himself, "I guess I'm so used to it. And anyway, it's not really supposed to be sitting there, it looks far better in the garden. Too big for indoors."
 
"Well, yeah, I didn't really take you for somone who'd keep that kind of thing as home decorations." The guy chuckled a bit. "Although some people do have pretty odd tastes in interior design."
 
"Such as?" he inquired as he switched off the kitchen light again and wrapped an arm around the guy's waist, thinking how oddly vulnerable being stark naked in such situations made one feel. "Let's go back to bed, hmm?"
 
"Sure." The guy felt responsive enough as they made their way to the bedrom. "I was thinking about all those hideous Victorian footstools made of elephant legs, and the like..."
 
"Oh yes, now that's what I call seriously creepy!" he had to admit. "Surely you haven't dated anyone with an elephant footstool?"
 
"Naah, my tastes don't really run towards elderly gentlemen, and that's frankly the only kind of person I can imagine to have such stuff in their houses," the guy said with a naughty little smirk. "I much prefer quite a bit younger gentlemen. Like you, for instance."
 
It was terribly difficult not to think about the creature lurking in the kitchen but the guy was good -- really good. Within minutes he was again engaged in a playful wrestling match, and this time they were not interrupted by any out-of-place noises or other disturbances. 
 
Afterwards they just lay there in a sweaty tangle, dozing off until physical need forced them to crawl up at last. The guy made for the bathroom and he took the opportunity to return to the kitchen, ostensibly to start the coffee. He kept glaring at the gargoyle on the kitchen top as if daring it to do something while he ran the water and let the cupboard doors clack and the mugs clink, but the infuriating thing stayed put. Only the occasional glint of its eyes told him that it had not given up.
 
The guy appeared at the door, grinning affably at him.  
 
"Hungry?" he asked pointing at the coffee maker. 
 
"Oh yeah." The guy looked greedy, then pointed at his naked self. "Can I come to breakfast like this?" 
 
He laughed. "I don't mind, but are you sure you want to? Yout butt will stick nastily to the chair, I warn you!" 
 
"You're right..." The guy disappeared again, and when he returned he wearing boxers. "This is better."
 
They munched their sandwiches in surprisingly companionable silence, exchanging smiles and winks and glances over their coffee mugs, and he couldn't help the waves of warmth that kept lapping his insides. Yeah, he was getting badly ahead of things but he couldn't help thinking how damnably easy it would be to get used to this... 
 
He shook himself awake from the daydream. "W-what did you say?" 
 
"I said that I could get used to this," the guy said, then made a face. "What, so you're already not listening to what I'm saying, huh?"
 
"It's not that," he stuttered, "just couldn't believe that you said exactly what I was thinking right then." 
 
The guy smiled. "Honest?"
 
"Honest," he replied. They looked incredulously at each other.
 
"You're just too good to be true, you know that?" The guy asked.  "I mean, here I was wondering if you'd be interested in going on with this, and then you say something like that."
 
Miraculously, the thing on the kitchen table didn't move a single claw during the entire long and leisurely breakfast; or if it did, neither of them noticed. Eventually the guy had to leave, but not before they had exchanged phone numbers, made sure the other each one got it exactly right, and shared a long kiss. 
 
He stood at the door watching as the guy walked out of the gate, turned to wave and smile, and made his way to the bus stop with brisk steps. 
 
Something brushed against the back of his legs and he spun around. There it was, sitting behind him with a cheeky smirk on its face.
 
"Okay," he growled at it, "now it's your turn! You tell me how you got into the house last night, or I swear I'm never going to buy another tin of cat food for you ever again." 
 
It licked its lips with that sharp dark tongue. He wasn't sure if that was a sign of uncertainty or amusement; he wished for the former.
 
"The back door wasn't locked," it said.
 
"It was closed," he pointed out. "And it sure as hell wasn't open when I came back."
 
"No, but it opens when I hang on the handle," was the answer.
 
He pictured the creature dangling from the door handle like a disgruntled bat, and nearly burst into laughter. Such a good thing that the view to the back side of the house was so shielded, quite by accident, that it was pretty much guaranteed that no one would be able to see there. He had sometimes worried that it offered a would-be burglar an ideal opportunity to work unnoticed, but right now that worry was the last thing on his mind. 
 
"Right," he said aloud. "And I guess it closes when you do the same on the inside, huh?"
 
"Yesss." 
 
He sighed. How was he going to be mad at the creature when he'd practically taught it every trick himself, routinely letting it in every night, buying endless boxes of cat food and, yes, even letting it sleep on his bed at night every now and then. In fact he'd rather got used to the feel of its warm, slightly leathery skin against his feet under the quilt...
 
"All right," he said. "But just so you know, I don't want you to come in on your own when I'm not here. And I really don't appreciate the kind of surprises you gave me last night! For one thing, why the hell were you in the kitchen, and why on the table? Why not in a corner, or... well, somewhere else. Anywhere else."
 
"Had no time," it said matter-of-factly. "I wanted to see what the noise was outside the house, when you came. And then you would've seen me if I had moved."
 
He rolled his eyes. All that might be true, or it might not, and of course the creature had been trying to figure out how to get to the cat food; it knew well wnough where he kept it. Before he could think of anything to say, though, the gargoyle slid next to him and its long tail curled around his ankles as it peered hopefully up to his face. "Cat food now? Pleasssse?" 
 
Its beady eyes glinted, head tilting in a way that was oddly endearing despite those big pointy ears and hairless head. He knew he had already given in.
 
"Okay, okay, just let me move."
 
Immediately the tail swiped away and the gargoyle hopped excitedly around him as he walked to the cupboard, took out a tin and opened the lid.
 
"You are totally spoiled rotten, you know that?" he asked and rolled his eyes when the thing attacked the food before the plate even touched the floor. "Although, well, who's to blame for that?" 
 
It was too busy to reply, and he couldn't help smiling as he watched its tail twitch excitedly while the chunk of cat food vanished from the plate. When the food was gone and the plate had been licked clean the gargoyle made a sound that was somewhere between a purr and a gurgle. 
 
"Happy now?" 
 
The gurgle rose in volume. He picked up the plate from the floor, rinsed it under the tap and slipped it into the dishwasher, then looked around in the kitchen. A day off, with nothing special to do, and it occurred to him that he could've in fact asked the guy to stay longer. Until the evening, maybe even for another night, although maybe that would have sounded too pushy. Or greedy. Or needy. Or maybe it would've been the right thing to do? He wasn't sure, and cursed himself for being so rusty, or -- why not use the right expression: he was simply unaccustomed to dating. 
 
Anyway, he hadn't asked, so that was that, and it would probably be downright silly to call when the guy had just left barely fifteen minutes earlier. He shrugged and strolled to the living room and wasn't in the least surprised at the sound of small feet that followed him, talons clicking faintly against the floor. 
 
He plopped on the sofa, wriggled into a comfortable position and stretched his arms above his head, stretching luxuriously. There was a quiet 'thump' and something pressed against his side.
 
"Is he coming back?" 
 
"Uhh, what?"
 
"I asked," the gargoyle said, pushing its head closer to his face, "if he is coming back. The man who slept in your bed last night."
 
"What if he is?" he asked lazily.
 
"Then you must tell him about me," it said, and this time there was no mistaking of the smug tone. 
 
He sighed. "Yes, I guess there's no way around it. Although things would be so much easier if you'd just stay out of doors. Like you should, you know!"
 
"Now you are mean," it said with an audible pout. "It is so boring there, nothing to do. Especially as you don't even let me catch mice and beetles, just sit and watch them."
 
"I do let you catch them!" he protested and got a snort in return.
 
"Only when it's dark enough," the gargoyle pointed out. "So I have to break the street lamp when it's not dark enough."
 
He stared at the thing. "So it's you? And I've thought it has something to do with the kids who play ball there every now and then."
 
The gargoyle looked pleased with itself -- a little too pleased? "Or maybe it is them after all. You just like to take credit for it, don't you?"
 
"Hmph." It curled up more comfortably against him. "So you don't believe me?"
 
"I just can't see how you could do it," he said, "after all it's -- uhhh!"
 
The gargoyle, suddenly grouched on his chest, peered staight into his face. 
 
"You forget that I can fly!" It stretched its wings up to their full length, then spread them over its back. 
 
"No, I remember it very well," he protested. "I just know that there is a thick glass protecting the lamp itself. I hope you haven't done anything stupid about the electric wires, because that is really dangerous." 
 
"I just hang on it. And shake it hard."
 
He blinked a few times, then burst into laughter. 
 
"What if someone sees you?" he asked. "I really don't think it would be a good thing."
 
"Why not?" it asked suspiciously. "You just try to make me stay on that one stone in your garden."
 
"No. You don't understand. Your kind are not supposed to exist, you know it, but neither is Nessie or, what's it called, Bigfoot, or all those other strange things people keep seeing. And whenever there's a supposed sighting, it means that lots of people immediately rush there and try to see it, too. Now, if someone says they've seen this strange winged thing hanging on a streetlamp, most people won't believe a word of it, but some will. And then there'll be all sorts of journalists and photographers and whatnot milling about on our street, waiting and trying to catch a glimpse or snap a photo. There'll be no quiet moment for a good while, and how would you like that?" 
 
The gargoyle's eyes narrowed in suspicion. "You are making it up."
 
"Nope. That's exactly what would happen. Take my word for it."
 
It seemed to consider for a while, then huffed and curled back into a roll, pressed to his hip. "All right. But I don't want to just sit there."
 
"Okay," he muttered, the fingers of one hand playing idly with the tip of the gargoyle's tail. "We'll try to think of something nice for you." 
[crossposted from Dreamwidth]

This afternoon, after coming home from work, we were sitting in the kitchen and having tea. I was sort of looking-but-yet-not out of the window, thinking about this and that, and registered this shape in my field of vision...

...then thought "no, honestly, there are no penguins around here".

One of the regular visitors to our bird feeder had just sat for a moment on top of the wheel of this old pushcart, and in the bright but slanted afternoon sunlight, seen through the leafless branches of a bush against extremely white snow, it really looked for a moment like a penguin sitting there with his back towards me. Heh. ^__^ 
[crossposted from Dreamwidth]

Nicked from scribblemoose : And, uh-oh, I probably shouldn't be doing this at all but let's go anyway!

First TV show I had self-insertion fantasies about:
Hmmmm. I'm very hazy about the timeline so I'm not sure whether the first one was this show about Skippy the bush kangaroo or "Pippi Långstrump" (I'm to blame for the fact that my brother's second name is Tommi... *headdesk*) -- but I don't think I was self-inserting that much at the time (or else I just don't remember). The first one I'm sure about is this one English show about young people working with horses, but I can't remember its name! In any case it was ages ago, as wll. I think I had a crush on the male lead... a dark-haired guy with sad Spaniel eyes. 

First fandom in which I interacted (online and in person) with other fans:
Whoa. It must've been Weiß Kreuz, and crazily enough I got into the fandom first through fanfic, a looooong time before I saw a single episode!

Pairing in the first slash fan fiction I read:
Oh boy. It must've been this one Robotech/Macross fic, with Lancer and Scott -- the original ones. It was a HUGE revelation.

First RPS/RPF I read:
Umm, I don't do RPS. At all. So I haven't really read any, because the few times I've accidentally started with one I've hurriedly ran away as soon as I've realized it's RPS.

First fan fiction I read that made me think, YES, this is exactly the kind of fan fiction I'd like to write…
I honestly can't pick just one name, because there are so many splendid writers around. And it's more like "YES this is how well I'd like to be able to write".

Pairing in the first fan fiction I wrote:
Heh... I've only ever written one single piece that could be classified as fan fiction: for an online manga "Your Wings Are Mine", and that was pretty much just about Killian being bitter to Ethan. Good grief, I haven't looked at that one for years... I ought to look it up again just to see what's happened.

First OTP: 
I don't think I really have one, although Crawford/Schuldig comes pretty close. 

First RPS/F OTP:
None.

First fannish friend I met in person: 
Yuki_Scorpio, at one of the London railway stations... soon thereafter we got to York for the first Squee and I met quite a few others!

First character I formally role-played/cosplayed:
Haven't role-played or cosplayed anyone -- but I've had Aya hair and I still have the Yohji jacket! *grin*  [crossposted from Dreamwidth]

So I'm going to post this thing, although I really don't know why I'm doing this. Probably just to get it off my back. *shrug* 

This is the Mini-NaNo thing I've now spent two Novembers working on, plus some time also in between & afterwards. I don't even have a name for it! Nothing to warn about in this part, either. Setting is a fictional universe, a kind of parallel Earth with completely different geography; the same place where most of my stuff takes place. 

*****

"Why, hello there."

 

They stared at each other over the ice cream. Both had deep brown eyes and dark hair, but that's where the similarities ended. The one holding the ice cream was tall, imposing and well groomed, whereas the one looking at said delicacy was shaggy, tall only when standing on his hind legs, and had put a wide paw on the seated man's knee.

 

Amused, the man shook his head. His adversary decided to ignore the gesture and focus on the smile, a more promising sign, and gave him a hopeful wag of tail.

 

"Listen," the man said lifting the ice cream a little higher up, "let me tell you that I'm used to your kind, so that pleading look isn't going to work on me."

 

The dog tilted its head and licked its wide, wet nose.

 

"Down," the man told it, hoping that the tone would do the trick even if he couldn't really expect the dog to understand the word. Instead of hopping down, though, the dog pushed itself away from his knee and then sat upright, long body swaying a little, a focused look on its hairy face.

 

"Oh boy!" The man had to laugh aloud at the display. "You're quite something, and I bet you know it well enough, don't you?"

 

He couldn't help it. He scooped a dollop of ice cream from his rapidly melting portion and let the dog lick it from his fingers while he hastily finished off the rest.

 

"And now we're pals for life, right?" he asked the dog, then straightened his back and looked around. There were many other humans sitting on the benches surrounding the statue in the middle of the small square, but no one seemed to be short of a hairy, low-to-ground dog.

 

All around the square there were small businesses: the ice cream shop he'd visited, a café, a bookstore, a bakery, a hair salon, their entrances alternating between doors leading to private residences. For a while the man eyed them all critically, then shrugged to himself. There was no way of knowing where the dog had come from. It could equally well be quite at home here, having just slipped out of the door when its owner was looking the other way, or it might belong to someone who'd just dropped in at any of the shops. Either way, he was sure it had an owner; the rough hair reaching nearly to the ground looked unruly but far from unkempt, and the dog’s behavior was a combination of self-confidence and friendliness that he'd never seen in strays. 

 

"Listen," he said as he stood up, "I think I'll be off on my way now, so you'd better trot home as well. No use following me around because I'm not going to buy any more ice creams today. Okay?"

 

The dog wagged its tail again, looking like it really enjoyed the conversation, and the tall man chuckled. Here he was, making a fool of himself in public once again – it was just so hard to remember that not everybody thought it a perfectly normal and natural thing to talk to dogs as if they understood every word. But at least for the moment nobody around him seemed to be giving him too odd looks. Perhaps they chose to shrug it off as yet another foreign eccentricity? 

 

He was just about to walk away when he heard a voice from behind.

 

"Duster? Damnit, Duster, where did you go again?"

 

The corner of the man's mouth pulled into a smile as he observed that his new friend seemed to recognize the name well enough. Only then did he realize that he'd immediately understood the words, and that could mean only one thing: the man who apparently owned the dog had spoken Revnashi.

 

So he replied in the same language.

 

"If Duster is a dog, I think I've got him right here." 

 

He had to raise his voice slightly to be heard across the square. The other man turned to look his way, and even though he was very slim and sported a long ponytail, there was no mistaking about the height or the very un-Dorelioni coloring: he had to be looking at a fellow countryman.

 

"Yes, that's definitely him!" Duster's owner walked towards him with a delighted smile, then frowned at the dog who jumped enthusiastically against his legs and let out a long gurgling growl. "Duster, you rascal, do I really need to start keeping you on a leash again? I told you to stay close!"

 

"Duster seems like a very appropriate name for him," the first man observed and got a grin in return.

 

"Yeah, doesn't it? Although nowadays I think 'Broom' would actually be even better because he's so good at sweeping the streets and depositing his catch all over the flat, but when he was a puppy he looked more like a feather duster so it stuck." 

 

He crouched to attach a leash to the dog's collar, then straightened himself again and smiled. "Anyway, thanks for, uhh, delaying him. He's a slippery fellow when he notices something he particularly likes. And since you don't seem to be in the company of a nubile and willing bitch, I might venture a guess – perhaps you then had an ice cream?"

 

The other man nodded and Duster's master rolled his eyes in mock desperation. "Wow, what a clairvoyant I am! Well, anyway, I'm glad he chose exactly you as his victim because it's always nice to meet other Revnashi! My name's Meliar."

 

"Shoriass," said the taller man and shook the offered hand. "Pleased to meet you – both of you!" 

 

A moment of awkward silence followed while both were trying to figure out how to go on from there. They'd met completely by chance, introducing oneself had been the only proper thing to do, and basically they were now free to go their separate ways with a nod in parting. But walking away didn't feel too polite to either of them and besides, even though it was by no means unusual to see another Revnashi in Dirna, it was still enough to arouse at least some curiosity. 

 

"Are you here for business or on holiday?" Meliar spoke at exactly the same moment when Shoriass asked: "So you live here?"

 

They paused and then laughed aloud. 

 

"Maybe we should flip a coin to decide who gets to speak first?" Meliar suggested with a chuckle. 

 

"That might be an idea," Shoriass agreed. "But, well, to answer your question: I guess this is mostly holiday for me, even though I did have something to do here. But not actual business, no."

 

"And have you liked it here? Have you got that something done?"

 

"The answer is yes, to both. And what about you? To me you look pretty well at home here."

 

"You're right there," Meliar said. "I moved here... let me see now... about six years ago. From County Adhelas."

 

"That's a long way!" Shoriass said. 

 

"It is, in more than one sense." Meliar smiled. "Of course I wouldn't have needed to come quite this far, but I'm not at all sorry that I decided to go a bit overboard when the doctor told me that a warmer climate might be good for me."

 

"Doctor?"

 

"Nothing more dramatic than being ill with bronchitis half of the time. It just kept getting worse every year, and by the time the Doc told me I should consider moving somewhere more southern I was so totally fed up with being miserable that I thought 'what the hell' and decided to go as far as I could possibly get." 

 

Shoriass nodded, then noticed in the corner of his eye that Duster was sitting smartly by his owner's side and listening to them, head turning towards whichever of them happened to be speaking at the time. Meliar, observing his amused expression, gave him a curious look and he hastened to explain: "It's Duster, I love the look on his face. Makes me feel so at home."

 

"So you're a dog person?" Meliar asked.

 

"Dog trainer," Shoriass specified. "In the Army."

 

"Wow!" Meliar's eyes went wide. "Now listen to that, Duster – I bet this guy could make even you learn some manners!"

 

Shoriass laughed a little. "There's no dog that cannot be taught at least something," he said, "but granted, some dogs are a lot harder to train than others. I bet Duster is a lot smarter than you think."

 

"Oh, he's smart all right, wouldn't I know that... fools me at least a dozen times a day, in different ways." Then Meliar glanced around. "But hey, were you going anywhere in particular? We could sit down, for example in that café, and talk a bit more. If you don't mind, that is."

 

"Mind? Not at all," Shoriass assured him. "My Dorelioni is very limited, to say the least, so it's nice to find new people to talk to. So far my talking has been pretty much limited to some acquaintances of my mother's, and the one person at my hotel who speaks Revnashi."

 

"Great! Then let's go, or would you rather go to some place where we could get something proper to eat?"

 

"No, I think I've got rather well used to eating late, local style."

 

Shoriass followed Meliar to the small café he'd observed earlier. The proprietor seemed to know the man and dog well enough, and when he brought their orders to the table there was also a small bowl of water and some over-baked cookies. Duster accepted these enthusiastically and then curled up around Meliar's feet under the table.

 

"I take it you come here often?" Shoriass asked after taking a few sips of his tea. "Do you live nearby?"

 

"Not quite, but I come to that bookstore at least once a week." Meliar paused to make sure that at least most of the crumbly thing he'd ordered ended up in his mouth and not all over him. "They also sell souvenirs and other stuff to visitors, and I bring my pictures there."

 

"Pictures?"

 

"Yeah, I'm an artist of sorts, and it's a nice way to get at least some regular income, painting those landscapes and cityscapes and other sights of Dirna that people buy to show the folks at home what this place looks like."

 

Shoriass nodded; he remembered seeing those pictures for sale in various places and thinking that he ought to bring some home with him. He hadn't really thought about returning home, not yet, but there was still plenty of time to buy souvenirs because his ship wouldn't leave for another several weeks. Strange how it seemed that he'd already been here a little eternity, and yet he had only arrived, what, two weeks ago? Three? 

 

And had Meliar just asked something? "Uh, sorry..."

 

"Never mind. You were thinking about something." Meliar looked curious. "Or about somebody – at home?"

 

"No, not really. I was just trying to figure out how long I've been here, and I think it's nearly three weeks now." Shoriass was a little embarrassed. "It feels weird to realize how time flies. I mean, how is it possible that I need to really think about it?"

 

"I don't think it's that odd," Meliar said. "When I first got here, everything was so different that it took me weeks before I could even start to make sense of Dirna. I was just walking around the city and looking at everything, the people, the houses, the streets, the shops, and being so overwhelmed by it all that I even slept far more than usual. All that kept me so busy that one day I was quite shocked to realize that I'd been here for two months even though I could've sworn that it had only been a few days at most!"

 

He looked at Shoriass over his cup of tea and then added: "So it's not surprising, especially if something momentous has happened to you."

 

Shoriass glanced at him, eyebrows rising in surprise. "What – what do you mean?"

 

"I just get this feeling," Meliar said mildly. "That coming here has meant something very special to you, and that you might want to talk about it to someone. Of course I realize that I'm a complete stranger, but if that's not too much of a problem, I'm here. And hey," he added, "I'm not saying this to pry, I'm totally fine with it if you don't want to talk to me. After all you only have my word that I'm not one to babble." 

 

Shoriass was speechless. Meliar met his gaze evenly and then shrugged a little. 

 

"Sorry," he said. "I'm sorry, didn't mean to upset you. All of a sudden you were just so deep in thought –"

 

"No, no," Shoriass interrupted, "no need to apologize, you just took me completely by surprise. And you were right, too. Absolutely right. These past couple of weeks have been... I mean, so much has happened and..."

 

He spread his hands, a desperate expression on his face. Meliar smiled a little and leaned back in his chair.

 

"Would it help if you told me about it?" he asked. "That is, of course you'd only tell me about things you feel like talking about."

 

"Maybe it would help." Shoriass combed fingers through short dark hair, eyebrows crunching. "My thoughts are in such a mess right now, and I don't really have anyone I could talk them over with!"

 

"Does it have something to do with your mother?" 

 

"What?" Shoriass looked surprised. "Good heavens, are you sure you really aren’t a clairvoyant?"

 

"Nothing of the kind," Meliar assured him. "It's just a bad habit of mine that when I meet someone new, I try to be especially observant. So far you’ve told me that you're here on holiday even though you did also have something to do; that you've been here for a couple of weeks; and that you’ve only really talked to your mother's acquaintances. So my guess is that either you came with your mother who knows people here, or she lives here and you came to see her – and either way I'm inclined to guess that this something special is related to her."

 

"All right. I choose to believe that you cannot read minds," Shoriass sighed. "Anyway, the second guess was right, I traveled alone. And yes, it's got to do with my mother."

 

For a while he was silent, picking on the crumbs of pastry left on his plate, then seemed to make up his mind and glanced up. "You see, I came here hoping to meet her... for the first time in my life."

Right now they're playing "To One In Paradise" by The Alan Parsons Project on the radio! WOOT! 

...this probably means nothing to anyone else, but anyway. I think I have all their albums, and used to listen to them over and over again. "The Tales of Mystery and Imagination" (from which that particular song is from) was the first one I ever heard, and was immediately hooked. Ohmigod, there are so many of their songs that tie very closely to so much in my life, and not least in all the stories and worlds and people in my head. As an example, it's hard to explain exactly how but "The Turn of a Friendly Card" is rather directly responsible to the birth of what is now the world of "ROaN", and even more specifically the Deleon Castle at the time the story takes place.

Whoa. The sheer amount of memories...

It's a running joke in our company that software can fix everything (or at least it's expected to), from actual hardware malfunctions to imbecile users' actions, and everything in between. 

Just a moment ago I went to one of the printer/copiers to get my printouts, and found a coworker who was adding paper to the machine. She was holding a stack of pre-punched paper.

Coworker A: Which way should I put this paper in so the holes would be where they should be?

Q: Damned if I know, it always seems to be the wrong way round...

Coworker B: *arrives* That's right. They always are.  

Q: Actually it's the paper manufacturer's fault, why do they punch the wrong edge of the papers?? 

Coworker A: That's true! Their fault! 

Coworker B: We should have software that fixes it, you know. 

Q: You mean something that sees which way the paper has been inserted and then prints on it the right way?

Coworker B: No, I mean software that'd move the holes to the other edge of the paper! 

*laughs*

Just skimmed over this article, and once again that whole attitude made me growl. What the heck is it with the expectation that after a certain age all people should like the same things? I think there are several things wrong with the assumption. One, it presupposes that a person who's, say, 45 years old today will be like someone who was 45 ten years ago, or twenty years ago. But this cannot be so, because these people were young at different times -- and even though tastes and preferences change over time, we still tend to like (or at least wax nostalgic over) stuff we liked when we were younger. Thus, even if my mum is still an Elvis fan and thinks that Gone With The Wind is the best film evah, there's nothing strange about it if I rather watch Star Wars (the original trilogy, puh-leeze, revamped is OK but not those horrid "beginnings") and squee when I hear FGTH or Human League on the radio. Shouldn't be so strange, really, considering that she was twenty years old in 1959 whereas for me that date came in 1983. Times change, baby. Two, it also presupposes that when you grow older, you can't get excited about new things and will be highly suspicious towards anything that wasn't available when you were younger. How much more wrong can you get? Okay, there are people like that, and it's also true that older people don't learn as quickly as younger ones, but that's beside the point. I remember when somebody in the bellydance group told about an interview she'd heard on the radio, they'd talked to a young teacher of modern dance in a local school. She'd said something about how "older people cannot really learn new steps anymore" and all of us just burst out laughing and saying "poor girl, grow up already" -- because there are people in the group who are in their early sixties now and still train as hard as everybody else, learning a few new choreographies a year. So, yeah. We can find new interests and learn new stuff at any age, as long as there's a spark of life inside. Thus, if a definitely grown-up person should find a new animated movie simply fantastic, or wants to have an mp3 player on their cellphone, what's so strange about it? I'm quite sure that the person would've done the same when they still were the "appropriate age" even in the writer's opinion -- if only those things had been available then!
Those young swallows are quite crazy. They're sitting all over the house, and making foolhardy sweeps back and forth, learning the mad  flying skillz. Whoa.
